Award.AwardTitle: SocraticGraphs: a Free-form Interactive Graphical Recognition System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is building on prior work (DUE-0735655) that produced OrganicPad, a free form, interactive, tablet-PC-based chemical structure drawing program. The PIs are developing SocraticGraphs - a web-based, cross platform system that recognizes student free-form input and provides tiered levels of contextual, "Socratic" feedback and support for learners as they construct graphical representations without the constraints usually imposed by computer based assessment and tutorial systems. SocraticGraphs provides a unique graphics-based interactive learning system designed to i) recognize and respond to student actions in a naturalistic manner and ii) facilitate studies on how students come to understand of scientific concepts, develop analytical representations and re-express and interpret data. This system is applicable to a wide range of disciplines including biology, chemistry, physics, geosciences, mathematics, and engineering.
The design of each activity is guided by preliminary research using pencil and paper tutorials, student interviews and direct observations of students as they work through preliminary versions of the on-line materials. The PIs are developing a range of activities in chemistry, physics and molecular biology, each of which will probe and respond with contextual Socratic feedback. The data from student responses are recorded and stored in a database for analysis using a number of data-mining techniques including Hidden Markov Modeling and Artificial Neural Nets. Ultimately, the project is providing activities that respond to student free-form input "on the fly" with the aim of developing analytical thinking skills and a robust and rigorous understanding of scientific phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
SocraticGraphs is an online formative assessment module that allows teachers to pose questions that require students to draw graphs, diagrams or simple pictures. For example, a student might be asked to draw a graph showing how variables are related, or draw a diagram of how energy is transferred in a molecular level system, or draw mechanistic arrows in an organic chemistry problem. We have developed a wide range of activities that range from general and organic chemistry, to molecular biology and mathematics. All of the student drawings are stored in the system and can be replayed, and for graphs and other fairly common types of representations we are able to recognize and respond to the student input.

 

Instructors can design activities in which they specify “rules” that the student performance must meet. Examples of such rules include: the number of maximums/minimums, area under the curve, slope, and intersections with coordinates or areas.  By combining such rules, activities designed with SocraticGraphs modules may be used in a large variety of STEM disciplines including mathematics, chemistry, biology, and engineering.  For example we might want students to draw a graph of the distribution of molecule velocities at a particular temperature. We would specify that the student draw graph that intersects with the origin, and has one maximum. It the student does not meet these rules the instructor can specify tiered contextual feedback that becomes increasingly specific, or send students to a new tutorial activity. Once students have correctly drawn a graph or diagram they can be asked to predict how the graph would change under different conditions, and the system can provide feedback based on the original and the new drawing.

 

We have subsequently incorporated SocraticGraphs into a more extensive formative assessment system, beSocratic, which combines different modules, such as text input, drawing, image and video capability among others. This system is currently in use with over 4000 students per semester, and the student data collected from it has been the basis for both curriculum reform and research on teaching and learning.
